image.altText: A women in a pink suits, sits on a pink armchair, holding three dogs.

props.synopsis: For decades, women in Australia have been told they should have more children for the good of the country, but  there's many reasons why more are choosing to stay child free.

title.children: Why it will take more than money to make Australian women have kids 'for the country'

image.altText: Kiwi crossing in New Zealand

props.synopsis: As New Zealanders grapple with high interest rates, stubborn inflation and general economic downturn, job losses have begun and more Kiwis than ever are leaving for good.

title.children: Every month, Australia gains 2,000 Kiwis as New Zealand's economy sheds jobs

image.altText: a composite image of a man going into the water at a perth and fog blankets sydney harbour

props.synopsis: For the second time this May, Australia's normally mobile weather systems have ground to a halt, with the coming week bringing another prolonged spell of invariable day-to-day weather.

title.children: Australia's weather map freezes for second time, laying the platform for record May in Perth, Adelaide and parts of NSW

image.altText: Golfer Scottie Scheffler in an orange jumpsuit in his mugshot.

props.synopsis: World number one Scottie Scheffler is detained by police just hours before the second round of the PGA Championship after trying to drive past a traffic incident.

title.children: World number one golfer arrested outside PGA Championship just before second round

image.altText: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese attends a rally to a call for action to end violence against women.

props.synopsis: Spending on domestic violence prevention in this year's budget was dwarfed by funds apportioned for fighting terrorism. Yet in the last three decades more than 1,500 women have been killed by intimate partners in Australia, compared with nine people killed in acts of terrorism. Is it time to change our approach?

title.children: Should we treat domestic violence like we treat terrorism?

image.altText: Snowtown accomplice Mark Haydon in a cap and jumper.

props.synopsis: Mark Ray Haydon, who was an accessory to Australia's worst serial killings, left the Adelaide pre-release centre on Thursday where he has been living on parole, the head of the Parole Board says.

title.children: Snowtown accomplice released into the community under strict supervision

image.altText: city buildings

props.synopsis: The operator of the Adelaide Casino and the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre agrees that $67 million is an appropriate penalty for SkyCity Adelaide's misconduct.

title.children: SkyCity Adelaide agrees to pay $67 million fine, but court will decide if penalty is appropriate

image.altText: Rows of solar panels in front of some wind turbines.

props.synopsis: The major desalination and water transport project in the Upper Spencer Gulf is still in the planning stage.

title.children: Federal government puts $65m towards SA water supply project

image.altText: Chad Warner holds his arms out in celebration of a goal

props.synopsis: The Sydney Swans tighten their grip on the top of the AFL ladder with a convincing 52-point win over Carlton in their traditional SCG Marn Grook match.

title.children: Sensational Swans in ominous form as they dominate Blues in SCG Marn Grook match

image.altText: Two young boys in white T-shirts stand in the foreground underneath an Israeli flag as smoke rises from a town in the distance.

props.synopsis: More than a dozen countries, including all the members of the Group of Seven (G7) major democracies apart from the United States, have signed the letter, which also says they are opposed to a full-scale Israeli military operation in Rafah.

title.children: Australia joins other democracies in letter urging Israel to comply with humanitarian law in Gaza

image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

props.synopsis: As far as mortgage-borrowers are concerned, a huge week in business, finance, economics and politics has seen interest rate forecasts go full circle back to expecting interest rate relief within a year.

title.children: After a huge week of economic news, where did we land on the direction of interest rates?

image.altText: A mum sits with her two kids in school uniform

props.synopsis: Alanah Scholes is a Gamilaroi Dunghutti mum trying to give her kids the best start to life but she's having to make tough choices as the cost-of-living bites.

title.children: This Indigenous family choosing gas heating or 'just rugging up' this winter is all of us

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: A jury hears longstanding friends of camper Russell Hill raised the alarm after he failed to join a nightly radio call. Mr Hill and his lover Carol Clay were allegedly murdered by Greg Lynn while on a camping trip in Victoria's High Country in 2020.

title.children: 'Those were the last words he spoke to me': Friends of killed camper give evidence in trial

image.altText: A zoomed-in view down an alleyway shows four men standing in front of a building marked with blue and yellow Stars of David.

props.synopsis: Police say officers were alerted early on Friday morning that smoke was rising from the synagogue, and came face to face with the man when they got there.

title.children: French police fatally shoot man suspected of trying to set fire to synagogue

image.altText: A person removing tattoos from a man's arm, both wearing protective glasses and sitting

props.synopsis: Pen ink, household paint, even watered-down ash — laser tattoo removalist Phil Pagdin has seen it all. He's among those in the industry concerned about the safety of home tattoo kits available to buy online.

title.children: Household paint, pen ink, and watered-down ash used in DIY tattoos prompt warnings over home kits

image.altText: Man in hospital receiving care

props.synopsis: International student Devarshi Deka had high hopes when he came to Australia. But an alleged assault has left him unable to walk, and his family is appealing for support so returning to India isn't his only option.

title.children: Dev came to Australia as a university student. He'll leave a paraplegic with no support

image.altText: Kieren appears close to tears, dressed in a black top and burgundy cardigan as she sits inside.

props.synopsis: A mother says a man armed with a knife told her to "just stop crying" as he forced her to drive and buy laptops in Melbourne's south-east while her six-month-old daughter sat in the back seat.

title.children: Melbourne mother recalls 'begging' armed abductor to leave her and daughter alone

image.altText: A bald man wearing a suit holds a gold-coloured card saying "Brazil" at a podium

props.synopsis: It will be the first time a South American nation has hosted the women's football tournament, preferred by FIFA over a joint bid from Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany.

title.children: Brazil announced as host of 2027 FIFA Women's World Cup

image.altText: Overturned rail cars with iron ore in them.

props.synopsis: The Mining and Energy Union has accused Rio Tinto of seriously downplaying the risks posed by this week's automated train crash in the Pilbara, including its concerns about spilled diesel contaminating water supplies.

title.children: Union accuses Rio Tinto of 'catastrophic' safety failure after automated train crash in Pilbara

image.altText: Vandals cut down 135-year-old statue of former Tasmanian premier William Crowther

props.synopsis: A statue of divisive colonial-era figure William Crowther has stood in central Hobart since 1889, that was until one night this week when it was toppled. Video has surfaced showing people carrying out the act.

title.children: Video of vandal toppling statue of controversial premier posted online as police investigate

image.altText: Split image of colourful lights in the sky and a singer standing on a platform with arms open

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Stunning auroras, federal budget handed down, and a history-making Eurovision

image.altText: Fatima Payman stands with her arms crossed inside her Parliament House office

props.synopsis: Federal government minister Ed Husic says it took “a lot of guts” for his colleague Fatima Payman to express concern over the Israel-Gaza war, but did not say whether he agreed with her assessment that it was committing genocide.

title.children: 'It takes a lot of guts': Husic backs Payman’s right to express concern over Israel's actions in Gaza

image.altText: Peter Dutton budget reply

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has used his budget reply speech to advocate a reduction to migration numbers.

title.children: Dutton calls to slash permanent migration and international student numbers

image.altText: A headshot of Liz Ellis commentating on TV during a Super Netball game.

props.synopsis: Netball Australia turns to retired World Cup-winning captain Liz Ellis to head up its board, with the legendary Diamond confident the sport will adopt a "united" front under her leadership.

title.children: Diamonds great elected new Netball Australia chair

image.altText: Gabrielle Morrissey

props.synopsis: Domestic, family and sexual violence organisations are warning they will need to start winding back services because the federal government hasn’t invested enough in the sector in its latest budget.

title.children: 'Trickery and deception': Frontline domestic violence services say federal budget a let-down

image.altText: Karoline Dawe and Kylie Ward wearing nice evening dresses outside a gala event.

props.synopsis: Senior executives at Australia's peak body for nurses have been sacked after an investigation found alleged "financial irregularities".

title.children: Head of nursing body sacked following financial investigation

image.altText: a composite image of Justin Stein who is accused of murdering nine-year-old Charlise Mutten in 2022

props.synopsis: A NSW Supreme Court jury is played the second police interview with Justin Stein that records a key difference from his first.

title.children: Alleged killer of 9yo girl changed story hours after first police interview, court told

image.altText: A smiling, young man in a dark suit.

props.synopsis: The 33-year-old Victorian doctor's family and community are still struggling to come to grips with the fatal stabbing earlier this year and Dr Gordon's sister says she wants to spare others the same pain.

title.children: Family of slain GP Ash Gordon calls for boost to police powers

image.altText: A man smiling in parliament

props.synopsis: Every budget week, a chorus of voices urges the opposition leader to "put some meat on the bones" of his alternative policy vision for the nation. This year is no different, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: Dutton's reply was everything we should expect: a calculated, ideological butchery of the most vulnerable budget bits

image.altText: Two middle aged women look at the camera and smile as they pose for a selfie.

props.synopsis: The first of the extra 1,000 security personnel France is sending to New Caledonia have started to arrive amid riots that have killed five people and injured hundreds more, with the French government saying a state of emergency has started to calm things in the Pacific territory.

title.children: Australians trapped in New Caledonia barricaded in accommodation for five days as violence spreads

image.altText: A glass of red wine on a  wooden veranda rail, overlooking a vineyard.

props.synopsis: Wine industry representatives say they will fight for financial assistance after this week's federal budget left them disappointed.

title.children: Wine industry warns regional communities at risk of collapse without aid for sector

image.altText: A vintage rusted truck lies on it's side

props.synopsis: The expansive red dirt plains of north-west Queensland are littered with the skeletons of hundreds of car bodies, but residents may have found a solution.

title.children: Rusted, burnt-out cars plaguing outback landscape that 'just don't belong here'

image.altText: A pile of discarded bottles and other rubbish in sand dunes

props.synopsis: A wildlife photographer says the amount of rubbish left in the dunes of South Australia's Goolwa Beach grows worse each year as the council and police consider how to better control access.

title.children: Permits to access famous beach on the cards as piles of litter show 'some people just don't care'

props.synopsis: Over the past decade in Broken Hill, the city's Sufi community has become more prominent, with the establishment of the locally revered Sufi Bakery, as well as an Islamic study centre and a Sufi bookshop.

title.children: With heart, soul, books and bread, the Sufi community calls this outback city home

image.altText: Head shot of Iranian man looking at the camera but body facing to the right with a desert background.

props.synopsis: Rapper Toomaj Salehi is facing the death penalty for using his music to draw attention to the actions of the Iranian government. Now artists and activists from around the world are trying to save him.

title.children: Rapper Toomaj Salehi's courage to speak out has won him fans all over the world. Now he's facing the death penalty
